title: Earthenware bowl touched by a lizard
vignette: A gecko falls into Robin's clay mixing bowl on the counter.

options.text: Discard the bowl; earthenware cannot be properly sanitized.
Simply rinse it and continue using.

title: Cracked pot still in use
vignette: A clay pot developed a small crack but can still hold soup.

options.text: It remains susceptible to contamination while it functions.
A cracked vessel is considered damaged and should be replaced.

title: Metal tool with removable handle
vignette: A saw's wooden handle detaches for storage. Does contamination on the blade spread to the handle?

options.text: Yes; they are treated as one when attached.
No; the handle is independent and remains clean.

title: Wooden bowl in a contaminated environment
vignette: A serving bowl was in the same room as hazardous materials.

options.text: Sanitize it thoroughly and it becomes safe again.
Wood absorbs contaminants permanently; discard it.

title: Glass cup lined with metal
vignette: A cracked glass cup was repaired with a metal rim.

options.text: It follows glass cleaning rules and can be sanitized.
The metal lining requires special cleaning protocols.

title: Utensil made from bone
vignette: Craftsmen fashioned spoons from animal bone.

options.text: Bone utensils require cleaning like wood.
Bone is considered stone and needs minimal cleaning.

title: Earthen oven repaired with plaster
vignette: An old clay oven cracked and was plastered over. Is it a new vessel?

options.text: Once repaired, it counts as new and free of prior contamination.
It retains its former contamination status despite repairs.

title: Imported pottery from a non-regulated source
vignette: Lena buys used clay jars from an unregulated supplier.

options.text: Discard them or modify them before use.
Sanitize them like metal utensils.

title: Nested cups stuck together
vignette: After washing, two cups dried stuck one inside the other.

options.text: They remain clean even if they touch contaminated surfaces together.
Treat each as separate; contamination on one spreads when stuck.

title: Steam carrying contamination through a kettle lid
vignette: A metal kettle sits over contaminated material; only steam reaches the lid.

options.text: Contamination travels with the steam to the lid.
Steam alone does not convey contamination upward.

title: Pan handle riveted to the body
vignette: A frying pan's handle is permanently riveted. Does contamination on the handle affect the pan?

options.text: Yes, they are one vessel for all cleaning purposes.
Only the pan proper matters; the handle can remain contaminated alone.

title: Clay jar without its lid
vignette: A storage jar lost its fitted lid. Is it still a complete vessel?

options.text: Without its lid it counts as damaged and harder to contaminate.
It remains susceptible to contamination since the body is whole.

title: Vessel built into the floor
vignette: A clay trough is cemented permanently into the ground.

options.text: Once fixed in place, it no longer needs regular sanitization.
It can still become contaminated like any utensil.

title: Professional utensil cracked in service
vignette: A small spoon used for precise measurements cracked during use.

options.text: Retire it immediately as invalid.
Continue using until a replacement is ready.

title: New synthetic material vessel
vignette: A modern bowl made from a plastic-like substance raises questions.

options.text: Treat it like earthenware with limited cleaning options.
Consider it like metal and allow standard sanitization.
